response:
The patient presents with a classic Brown-Séquard syndrome: ipsilateral (right-sided) upper motor neuron weakness (spasticity, hyperreflexia, upgoing plantar) and dorsal column sensory loss (proprioception/vibration), combined with contralateral (left-sided) spinothalamic sensory loss (pain/temperature). The presence of severe respiratory difficulty implicates the phrenic nerve nuclei or descending respiratory pathways (C3-C5). The right upper limb hypotonia suggests lower motor neuron involvement at the level of the lesion, while the lower limb spasticity indicates descending tract involvement below the lesion.

lesion_locations = ["Right High Cervical Spinal Cord"]
